Linear algebra

This file defines the basics of linear algebra. It sets up the "categorical/lattice structure" of modules over a ring, submodules, and linear maps. If p and q are submodules of a module, p ≤ q means that p ⊆ q.

Many of the relevant definitions, including module, submodule, and linear_map, are found in src/algebra/module.lean.

Main definitions

  • Many constructors for linear maps, including prod and coprod
  • submodule.span s is defined to be the smallest submodule containing the set s.
  • If p is a submodule of M, submodule.quotient p is the quotient of M with respect to p: that is, elements of M are identified if their difference is in p. This is itself a module.
  • The kernel ker and range range of a linear map are submodules of the domain and codomain respectively.
  • linear_equiv M M₂, the type of linear equivalences between M and M₂, is a structure that extends linear_map and equiv.
  • The general linear group is defined to be the group of invertible linear maps from M to itself.

Main statements

  • The first and second isomorphism laws for modules are proved as quot_ker_equiv_range and quotient_inf_equiv_sup_quotient.

Notations

  • We continue to use the notation M →ₗ[R] M₂ for the type of linear maps from M to M₂ over the ring R.
  • We introduce the notations M ≃ₗ M₂ and M ≃ₗ[R] M₂ for linear_equiv M M₂. In the first, the ring R is implicit.

Implementation notes

We note that, when constructing linear maps, it is convenient to use operations defined on bundled maps (prod, coprod, arithmetic operations like +) instead of defining a function and proving it is linear.

Tags

linear algebra, vector space, module

c • v.sum h = v.sum (λ (a : α) (b : β), c • h a b)

theorem pi_eq_sum_univ {ι : Type u} [fintype ι] {R : Type v} [semiring R] (x : ι → R) :
x = finset.univ.sum (λ (i : ι), x i • λ (j : ι), ite (i = j) 1 0)

decomposing x : ι → R as a sum along the canonical basis

def linear_map.cod_restrict {R : Type u} {M : Type v} {M₂ : Type w} [ring R] [add_comm_group M] [add_comm_group M₂] [module R M] [module R M₂] (p : submodule R M) (f : M₂ →ₗ[R] M) :
(∀ (c : M₂), ⇑f c ∈ p) → (M₂ →ₗ[R] ↥p)

A linear map f : M₂ → M whose values lie in a submodule p ⊆ M can be restricted to a linear map M₂ → p.

Equations
  • linear_map.cod_restrict p f h = {to_fun := λ (c : M₂), ⟨⇑f c, _⟩, add := _, smul := _}

↑(⇑(linear_map.cod_restrict p f h) x) = ⇑f x

def linear_map.inverse {R : Type u} {M : Type v} {M₂ : Type w} [ring R] [add_comm_group M] [add_comm_group M₂] [module R M] [module R M₂] (f : M →ₗ[R] M₂) (g : M₂ → M) :
function.left_inverse g ⇑f → function.right_inverse g ⇑f → (M₂ →ₗ[R] M)

If a function g is a left and right inverse of a linear map f, then g is linear itself.

Equations
  • f.inverse g h₁ h₂ = id (λ (h₂ : ∀ (x : M₂), ⇑f (g x) = x), id (λ (h₁ : ∀ (x : M), g (⇑f x) = x), {to_fun := g, add := _, smul := _}) h₁) h₂

theorem linear_map.sum_apply {R : Type u} {M : Type v} {M₂ : Type w} {ι : Type x} [ring R] [add_comm_group M] [add_comm_group M₂] [module R M] [module R M₂] (t : finset ι) (f : ι → (M →ₗ[R] M₂)) (b : M) :
⇑(t.sum f) b = t.sum (λ (d : ι), ⇑(f d) b)

⇑(f - g) x = ⇑f x - ⇑g x

def linear_map.smul_right {R : Type u} {M : Type v} {M₂ : Type w} [ring R] [add_comm_group M] [add_comm_group M₂] [module R M] [module R M₂] :
(M₂ →ₗ[R] R) → M → (M₂ →ₗ[R] M)

λb, f b • x is a linear map.

Equations
  • f.smul_right x = {to_fun := λ (b : M₂), ⇑f b • x, add := _, smul := _}

theorem submodule.span_induction {R : Type u} {M : Type v} [ring R] [add_comm_group M] [module R M] {x : M} {s : set M} {p : M → Prop} :
x ∈ submodule.span R s → (∀ (x : M), x ∈ s → p x) → p 0 → (∀ (x y : M), p x → p y → p (x + y)) → (∀ (a : R) (x : M), p x → p (a • x)) → p x

An induction principle for span membership. If p holds for 0 and all elements of s, and is preserved under addition and scalar multiplication, then p holds for all elements of the span of s.

def linear_map.ker {R : Type u} {M : Type v} {M₂ : Type w} [ring R] [add_comm_group M] [add_comm_group M₂] [module R M] [module R M₂] :
(M →ₗ[R] M₂) → submodule R M

The kernel of a linear map f : M → M₂ is defined to be comap f ⊥. This is equivalent to the set of x : M such that f x = 0. The kernel is a submodule of M.

Equations
  • f.ker = submodule.comap f ⊥

y ∈ f.ker ↔ ⇑f y = 0

  • submodule.comap_mkq.lt_order_embedding p = (submodule.comap_mkq.le_order_embedding p).lt_embedding_of_le_embedding
view source
@[nolint]
structure linear_equiv (R : Type u) (M : Type v) (M₂ : Type w) [ring R] [add_comm_group M] [add_comm_group M₂] [module R M] [module R M₂] :
Type (max v w)
  • to_fun : M → M₂
  • add : ∀ (x y : M), c.to_fun (x + y) = c.to_fun x + c.to_fun y
  • smul : ∀ (c_1 : R) (x : M), c.to_fun (c_1 • x) = c_1 • c.to_fun x
  • inv_fun : M₂ → M
  • left_inv : function.left_inverse c.inv_fun c.to_fun
  • right_inv : function.right_inverse c.inv_fun c.to_fun

A linear equivalence is an invertible linear map.

view source

(M ≃ₗ[R] M₂) → (M →ₗ[R] M₂)

Equivalence given by a block lower diagonal matrix. e₁ and e₂ are diagonal square blocks, and f is a rectangular block below the diagonal.

Equations
  • e₁.skew_prod e₂ f = {to_fun := ((↑e₁.comp (linear_map.fst R M M₃)).prod (↑e₂.comp (linear_map.snd R M M₃) + f.comp (linear_map.fst R M M₃))).to_fun, add := _, smul := _, inv_fun := λ (p : M₂ × M₄), (⇑(e₁.symm) p.fst, ⇑(e₂.symm) (p.snd - ⇑f (⇑(e₁.symm) p.fst))), left_inv := _, right_inv := _}

def linear_equiv.of_bijective {R : Type u} {M : Type v} {M₂ : Type w} [ring R] [add_comm_group M] [add_comm_group M₂] {module_M : module R M} {module_M₂ : module R M₂} (f : M →ₗ[R] M₂) :

def linear_equiv.arrow_congr {R : Type u_1} {M₁ : Type u_2} {M₂ : Type u_3} {M₂₁ : Type u_4} {M₂₂ : Type u_5} [comm_ring R] [add_comm_group M₁] [add_comm_group M₂] [add_comm_group M₂₁] [add_comm_group M₂₂] [module R M₁] [module R M₂] [module R M₂₁] [module R M₂₂] :
(M₁ ≃ₗ[R] M₂) → (M₂₁ ≃ₗ[R] M₂₂) → ((M₁ →ₗ[R] M₂₁) ≃ₗ[R] M₂ →ₗ[R] M₂₂)

A linear isomorphism between the domains and codomains of two spaces of linear maps gives a linear isomorphism between the two function spaces.

Equations
  • e₁.arrow_congr e₂ = {to_fun := λ (f : M₁ →ₗ[R] M₂₁), e₂.to_linear_map.comp (f.comp e₁.symm.to_linear_map), add := _, smul := _, inv_fun := λ (f : M₂ →ₗ[R] M₂₂), e₂.symm.to_linear_map.comp (f.comp e₁.to_linear_map), left_inv := _, right_inv := _}
view source

(M₂ ≃ₗ[R] M₃) → ((M →ₗ[R] M₂) ≃ₗ[R] M →ₗ[R] M₃)

The general linear group on R and M is multiplicatively equivalent to the type of linear equivalences between M and itself.

Equations
  • linear_map.general_linear_group.general_linear_equiv R M = {to_fun := linear_map.general_linear_group.to_linear_equiv _inst_5, inv_fun := linear_map.general_linear_group.of_linear_equiv _inst_5, left_inv := _, right_inv := _, map_mul' := _}
view source
@[simp]
theorem linear_map.general_linear_group.general_linear_equiv_to_linear_map (R : Type u) (M : Type v) [ring R] [add_comm_group M] [module R M] (f : linear_map.general_linear_group R M) :
↑(⇑(linear_map.general_linear_group.general_linear_equiv R M) f) = ↑f
